title: 107_s1656
content: The Act titled "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing claims for veterans compensation and pension, accuracy has been a concern, with a reported 95 percent accuracy rate in the past. The Systematic Technical Accuracy Review found that initial reviews of veterans claims were accurate only 64% of the time in 1998 and 2000. The Veterans Benefits Administration may lose up to 30% of its workforce to retirement by 2003, highlighting the need for adequate training for claims adjudicators. It is crucial for the administration to take more aggressive steps to ensure accurate and timely processing of veterans claims to avoid unnecessary delays. In 2001, the Veterans Benefits Administration faced a backlog of 533,029 pending claims, with an expected appeals processing time of 621 days from notice of disagreement to final decision. Improvement of processing of veterans benefits claims. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan within 90 days of this Act's enactment to improve the processing of veterans' compensation and pension claims. The plan should include mechanisms for better training of claims adjudicators and enhancing employee accountability standards to ensure thorough initial reviews of claims. The plan must include mechanisms for improving the Veterans Benefits Administration's ability to identify recurring errors in claims adjudications by enhancing data collection and management related to common disabilities and deficiencies in medical evidence. The plan must include mechanisms for improving the accuracy of disability and pension claims processing by addressing recurring deficiencies in medical evidence and examinations, implementing a system for reviewing claims processing accuracy, evaluating the impact of the Training and Performance Support System, and setting quantifiable goals for each mechanism. The Secretary must consult with veterans organizations and other parties to develop a plan for improving claims processing accuracy. The plan must include quantifiable goals for each mechanism and can be modified as needed. Implementation begins 60 days after plan submission. The Secretary may modify the plan for improving claims processing accuracy, with any modifications taking effect 30 days after notice is provided to relevant committees. Reports on the plan's progress must be submitted every six months to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must submit a report every six months to assess the implementation of the plan for improving claims processing accuracy, including whether goals are being achieved. Funding for the plan will come from appropriations for the Veterans Benefits Administration.
